title: Throne room
data:
A **throne room** is a type of [special room](/wiki/Special_room "Special room") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, and contains an assortment of [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster"), a [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne"), and a [chest](/wiki/Chest "Chest").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)
  - [1.1 Special levels with throne rooms](#Special_levels_with_throne_rooms)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Messages](#Messages)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 GruntHack](#GruntHack)
  - [5.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.3 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

A throne room is generated with a 1⁄6 chance on ordinary rooms-and-corridors levels from dungeon level 5 onwards, and will only generate if the level does not already have a [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) The monsters in the throne room will always be generated as hostile and [asleep](/wiki/Asleep "Asleep").[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

The list of [throne room monsters](/wiki/Throne_room_monster "Throne room monster") is as follows:[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

- [dragons](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon") (on level 15+)
- [giant humanoids](/wiki/Giant_humanoid "Giant humanoid") (13+)
- [trolls](/wiki/Troll_\(monster_class\) "Troll (monster class)") (10+)
- [centaurs](/wiki/Centaur_\(monster_class\) "Centaur (monster class)") (6+)
- [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_class\) "Orc (monster class)")
- [bugbears](/wiki/Bugbear "Bugbear")
- [hobgoblins](/wiki/Hobgoblin "Hobgoblin")
- [gnomes](/wiki/Gnome_\(monster_class\) "Gnome (monster class)")
- [kobolds](/wiki/Kobold_\(monster_class\) "Kobold (monster class)")

Deeper levels are skewed to harder monsters. The limits for ordinary random monsters (based on the average of your and the dungeon floor's level) do not apply. Extinct or genocided monsters from a monster class will be replaced with ordinary random monsters, with the exception of hobgoblins and bugbears.

Additionally, the throne will have one of the following monsters occupying it based on [monster difficulty](/wiki/Monster_difficulty "Monster difficulty"), and they are generated with a [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace") in addition to their usual [starting inventory](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory"):[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

- [ogre king](/wiki/Ogre_king "Ogre king")
- [Elvenking](/wiki/Elvenking "Elvenking")
- [dwarf king](/wiki/Dwarf_king "Dwarf king")
- [gnome king](/wiki/Gnome_king "Gnome king")

### Special levels with throne rooms

There is a guaranteed throne room in [Fort Ludios](/wiki/Fort_Ludios "Fort Ludios") (if the Fort is generated at all), with [Croesus](/wiki/Croesus "Croesus") seated on the throne.

While there are also guaranteed thrones in the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") and in [Vlad's Tower](/wiki/Vlad%27s_Tower "Vlad's Tower"), the rooms they are located in are not considered throne rooms.

## Strategy

Fighting all the monsters when they are awake can be dangerous for low-level characters, as most of the monsters can generate with [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") to use against you. Additionally, it is possible for early throne rooms with an otherwise-out of depth monster on the throne to generate - beware the Elvenking who rules over the sixth level!

If you have [stealth](/wiki/Stealth "Stealth"), you can carefully pick off the denizens of a throne room one by one—most throne room monsters are slower than an unhasted player, making them vulnerable to hit-and-run, ranged attacks and/or funneling them into outside hallways. Centaurs are the fastest throne room monsters that can generate, and pose the biggest obstace to the above strategies—they often generate with ranged weapons of their own, and may hit you several times per turn in [melee](/wiki/Melee "Melee").

If luring throne room monsters into a hallway to fight, beware of monsters zapping a [wand of digging](/wiki/Wand_of_digging "Wand of digging") down and leaving a hole between you and the throne room.

## History

Throne rooms first appear in [NetHack 1.3d](/wiki/NetHack_1.3d "NetHack 1.3d"). From this version to [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0"), "royal" monsters could generate randomly in throne rooms, but a specific ruler was not placed on the throne (with the exception of Croesus). [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1") adds rulers to throne rooms via [commit 4d7d638](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/4d7d63814a99b14acf0bcc96ddf567e966064b78) and gives them a mace; this is based on a patch by [Leon Arnott](/wiki/L_\(person\) "L (person)").[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

## Messages

- You hear the tones of courtly conversation.  
  You hear a sceptre pounded in judgment.  
  Someone shouts "Off with \<his/her> head!"

  An occupied throne room is present on the level; the pronoun used matches that of the player character.

- You hear Queen Beruthiel's cats!

  As above while [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating").

- You enter an opulent throne room!

  You entered an occupied throne room.

## Variants

Some variants based on [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and earlier versions place a "royal" monster on the throne, and some of them additionally provide the monster with an enchanted mace or similar weapon.

### GruntHack

[GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack") always generates a [king or queen](/wiki/King_\(GruntHack\) "King (GruntHack)") [racial monster](/wiki/Racial_monster "Racial monster") on the throne of a throne room - this implementation is much different from the L patch that was eventually merged into vanilla *NetHack*.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), 3⁄4 of throne rooms have a specific ruler with a court of particular monsters accompanying them. Rulers are chosen according to their monster difficulty: a chosen ruler will not have a difficulty greater than the average of your level and the dungeon level difficulty + 5, and will not be lower than 2⁄3 of the dungeon level difficulty. If no prospective ruler fits these criteria, the standard set of throne room rulers are used instead.

The ruler types and corresponding monsters for each room are as follows, roughly sorted in order of monster difficulty:

- [Kobold lord](/wiki/Kobold_lord "Kobold lord") (difficulty 3): [Kobold shaman](/wiki/Kobold_shaman "Kobold shaman"), [large kobold](/wiki/Large_kobold "Large kobold"), [kobold](/wiki/Kobold "Kobold"), [lemure](/wiki/Lemure "Lemure"), [imp](/wiki/Imp "Imp").
- [Gnome king](/wiki/Gnome_king "Gnome king") or [gnome queen](/wiki/Gnome_queen_\(dNetHack\) "Gnome queen (dNetHack)") (difficulty 6): [Gnome lord](/wiki/Gnome_lord "Gnome lord"), [gnome lady](/wiki/Gnome_lady_\(dNetHack\) "Gnome lady (dNetHack)"), [gnome](/wiki/Gnome_\(monster\) "Gnome (monster)"), [gnomish wizard](/wiki/Gnomish_wizard "Gnomish wizard"), [tinker gnome](/wiki/Tinker_gnome "Tinker gnome"), [dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster\) "Dwarf (monster)"), [dwarf lord](/wiki/Dwarf_lord "Dwarf lord"), [dwarf cleric](/wiki/Dwarf_cleric "Dwarf cleric"), [hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit"), [leprechaun](/wiki/Leprechaun "Leprechaun"), [homunculus](/wiki/Homunculus "Homunculus").
- [Orc-captain](/wiki/Orc-captain "Orc-captain") (difficulty 7): [Orc shaman](/wiki/Orc_shaman "Orc shaman"), [Mordor orc](/wiki/Mordor_orc "Mordor orc"), [hill orc](/wiki/Hill_orc "Hill orc"), [hobgoblin](/wiki/Hobgoblin "Hobgoblin"), [goblin](/wiki/Goblin "Goblin"), [manes](/wiki/Manes "Manes"), [quasit](/wiki/Quasit "Quasit").
- [Dwarf king](/wiki/Dwarf_king "Dwarf king") or [dwarf queen](/wiki/Dwarf_queen_\(dNetHack\) "Dwarf queen (dNetHack)") (difficulty 8): [Dwarf lord](/wiki/Dwarf_lord "Dwarf lord"), [dwarf cleric](/wiki/Dwarf_cleric "Dwarf cleric"), [dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(monster\) "Dwarf (monster)"), [gnome](/wiki/Gnome_\(monster\) "Gnome (monster)"), [gnome lord](/wiki/Gnome_lord "Gnome lord"), [gnome lady](/wiki/Gnome_lady_\(dNetHack\) "Gnome lady (dNetHack)"), [gnomish wizard](/wiki/Gnomish_wizard "Gnomish wizard"), [hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit"), [leprechaun](/wiki/Leprechaun "Leprechaun").
- [Ogre king](/wiki/Ogre_king "Ogre king") (difficulty 11): [Ogre mage](/wiki/Ogre_mage "Ogre mage"), [ogre lord](/wiki/Ogre_lord "Ogre lord"), [ogre](/wiki/Ogre "Ogre"), [orc-captain](/wiki/Orc-captain "Orc-captain"), [Mordor orc](/wiki/Mordor_orc "Mordor orc"), [tengu](/wiki/Tengu "Tengu"), [troll](/wiki/Troll "Troll"), random [H](/wiki/Giant_humanoid "Giant humanoid").
- [Elvenking](/wiki/Elvenking "Elvenking") or [Elvenqueen](/wiki/Elvenqueen_\(dNetHack\) "Elvenqueen (dNetHack)") (difficulty 14): [Elf-lord](/wiki/Elf-lord "Elf-lord"), [elf-lady](/wiki/Elf-lady_\(dNetHack\) "Elf-lady (dNetHack)"), [Grey-elf](/wiki/Grey-elf "Grey-elf"), [Green-elf](/wiki/Green-elf "Green-elf"), [Woodland-elf](/wiki/Woodland-elf "Woodland-elf"), [quickling](/wiki/Quickling "Quickling"), [dryad](/wiki/Dryad "Dryad"), [naiad](/wiki/Naiad "Naiad"), [Coure Eladrin](/wiki/Eladrin#Coure_Eladrin "Eladrin"), [Noviere Eladrin](/wiki/Eladrin#Noviere_Eladrin "Eladrin"), [Bralani Eladrin](/wiki/Eladrin#Bralani_Eladrin "Eladrin"), [Firre Eladrin](/wiki/Eladrin#Firre_Eladrin "Eladrin"), [Shiere Eladrin](/wiki/Eladrin#Shiere_Eladrin "Eladrin"), [doppelganger](/wiki/Doppelganger "Doppelganger"), [wood troll](/wiki/Wood_troll "Wood troll").
- [Vampire lord](/wiki/Vampire_lord "Vampire lord") or [vampire lady](/wiki/Vampire_lady_\(dNetHack\) "Vampire lady (dNetHack)") (difficulty 14): [Vampire](/wiki/Vampire "Vampire"), random [Z](/wiki/Zombie_\(dNetHack\) "Zombie (dNetHack)"), random [M](/wiki/Mummy "Mummy"), [flesh golem](/wiki/Flesh_golem "Flesh golem"), [werewolf](/wiki/Werewolf "Werewolf"), [floating eye](/wiki/Floating_eye "Floating eye"), [gargoyle](/wiki/Gargoyle "Gargoyle"), [winged gargoyle](/wiki/Winged_gargoyle "Winged gargoyle"), [quasit](/wiki/Quasit "Quasit"), [black pudding](/wiki/Black_pudding "Black pudding"), [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith"), [phantasm](/wiki/Phantasm "Phantasm"), [ghost](/wiki/Ghost "Ghost"), [maid](/wiki/Maid "Maid"), [weeping willow](/wiki/Weeping_willow "Weeping willow"), [swamp nymph](/wiki/Swamp_nymph "Swamp nymph").
- [Drow matron](/wiki/Drow_matron "Drow matron") (difficulty 15): [Unearthly drow](/wiki/Unearthly_drow "Unearthly drow"), [hedrow wizard](/wiki/Hedrow_wizard "Hedrow wizard"), [hedrow warrior](/wiki/Hedrow_warrior "Hedrow warrior"), [drow](/wiki/Drow "Drow"), [sprow](/wiki/Sprow "Sprow"), [swamp nymph](/wiki/Swamp_nymph "Swamp nymph"), [giant spider](/wiki/Giant_spider "Giant spider"), [cave lizard](/wiki/Cave_lizard "Cave lizard"), [large cave lizard](/wiki/Large_cave_lizard "Large cave lizard"), [quasit](/wiki/Quasit "Quasit").
- [Titan](/wiki/Titan "Titan") (difficulty 20): [Storm giant](/wiki/Storm_giant "Storm giant"), [fire giant](/wiki/Fire_giant "Fire giant"), [frost giant](/wiki/Frost_giant "Frost giant"), [hill giant](/wiki/Hill_giant "Hill giant"), [stone giant](/wiki/Stone_giant "Stone giant"), [giant](/wiki/Giant_\(monster\) "Giant (monster)"), [son of Typhon](/wiki/Son_of_Typhon "Son of Typhon"), [dryad](/wiki/Dryad "Dryad"), [naiad](/wiki/Naiad "Naiad"), [oread](/wiki/Oread "Oread"), [deminymph](/wiki/Deminymph "Deminymph").
- [Embraced drowess](/wiki/Embraced_drowess "Embraced drowess") (difficulty 27): [Drow alienist](/wiki/Drow_alienist "Drow alienist"), [hedrow blademaster](/wiki/Hedrow_blademaster "Hedrow blademaster"), [edderkop](/wiki/Edderkop "Edderkop"), [hedrow wizard](/wiki/Hedrow_wizard "Hedrow wizard"), [hedrow warrior](/wiki/Hedrow_warrior "Hedrow warrior"), [drow mummy](/wiki/Drow_mummy "Drow mummy").
- [Deepest one](/wiki/Deepest_one "Deepest one") (difficulty 33): [Deeper one](/wiki/Deeper_one "Deeper one"), [deep one](/wiki/Deep_one "Deep one"), [human](/wiki/Human "Human"), [mind flayer](/wiki/Mind_flayer "Mind flayer"), [dark young](/wiki/Dark_young "Dark young"), [umber hulk](/wiki/Umber_hulk "Umber hulk"), [stumbling](/wiki/Stumbling_horror "Stumbling horror"), [wandering](/wiki/Wandering_horror "Wandering horror"), and [shambling horrors](/wiki/Shambling_horror_\(dNetHack\) "Shambling horror (dNetHack)").
- [Orc of the ages of stars](/wiki/Orc_of_the_ages_of_stars "Orc of the ages of stars") (difficulty 37): [Deep wyrm](/wiki/Deep_wyrm "Deep wyrm"), [red dragon](/wiki/Red_dragon "Red dragon"), [white dragon](/wiki/White_dragon "White dragon"), [black dragon](/wiki/Black_dragon "Black dragon"), [blue dragon](/wiki/Blue_dragon "Blue dragon"), [angband orc](/wiki/Angband_orc "Angband orc"), [hedrow blademaster](/wiki/Hedrow_blademaster "Hedrow blademaster"), [succubus](/wiki/Succubus "Succubus"), [incubus](/wiki/Incubus "Incubus"), [olog-hai](/wiki/Olog-hai "Olog-hai"), [siege ogre](/wiki/Siege_ogre "Siege ogre"), [hell hound](/wiki/Hell_hound "Hell hound").

Some throne rooms have prisoners with a [set of shackles](/index.php?title=Set_of_shackles\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Set of shackles (page does not exist)") that are unconscious and trapped in closets behind [iron bars](/wiki/Iron_bars "Iron bars"), with the starting inventory they would have normally received placed in that throne room's chest. A character can #[untrap](/wiki/Untrap "Untrap") these prisoners to free them, which also has a chance of pacifying hostile prisoners if successful.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), a royal monster always occupies the throne of a throne room, and they are always generated with an [ornate mace](/wiki/Ornate_mace_\(SpliceHack\) "Ornate mace (SpliceHack)").

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 411](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkroom.c#L411)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 763](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mklev.c#L763)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 348](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkroom.c#L348)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 738](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkroom.c#L738)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 247](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkroom.c#L247)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [Zoos and Courts patch](https://web.archive.org/web/20180902003105/http://l.j-factor.com/nethack/mkroom.diff) on an archive of L's website

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Throne room

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

A throne room is a type of special room that appears in NetHack, and contains an assortment of monsters, a throne, and a chest.[1]

Contents

  • 1 Generation
    • 1.1 Special levels with throne rooms
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Messages
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 GruntHack
    • 5.2 dNetHack
    • 5.3 SlashTHEM
  • 6 References

Generation

A throne room is generated with a 1⁄6 chance on ordinary rooms-and-corridors levels from dungeon level 5 onwards, and will only generate if the level does not already have a shop.[2] The monsters in the throne room will always be generated as hostile and asleep.[3]

The list of throne room monsters is as follows:[4]

  • dragons (on level 15+)
  • giant humanoids (13+)
  • trolls (10+)
  • centaurs (6+)
  • orcs
  • bugbears
  • hobgoblins
  • gnomes
  • kobolds

Deeper levels are skewed to harder monsters. The limits for ordinary random monsters (based on the average of your and the dungeon floor's level) do not apply. Extinct or genocided monsters from a monster class will be replaced with ordinary random monsters, with the exception of hobgoblins and bugbears.

Additionally, the throne will have one of the following monsters occupying it based on monster difficulty, and they are generated with a mace in addition to their usual starting inventory:[5]

  • ogre king
  • Elvenking
  • dwarf king
  • gnome king

Special levels with throne rooms

There is a guaranteed throne room in Fort Ludios (if the Fort is generated at all), with Croesus seated on the throne.

While there are also guaranteed thrones in the Castle and in Vlad's Tower, the rooms they are located in are not considered throne rooms.

Strategy

Fighting all the monsters when they are awake can be dangerous for low-level characters, as most of the monsters can generate with wands to use against you. Additionally, it is possible for early throne rooms with an otherwise-out of depth monster on the throne to generate - beware the Elvenking who rules over the sixth level!

If you have stealth, you can carefully pick off the denizens of a throne room one by one—most throne room monsters are slower than an unhasted player, making them vulnerable to hit-and-run, ranged attacks and/or funneling them into outside hallways. Centaurs are the fastest throne room monsters that can generate, and pose the biggest obstace to the above strategies—they often generate with ranged weapons of their own, and may hit you several times per turn in melee.

If luring throne room monsters into a hallway to fight, beware of monsters zapping a wand of digging down and leaving a hole between you and the throne room.

History

Throne rooms first appear in NetHack 1.3d. From this version to NetHack 3.6.0, "royal" monsters could generate randomly in throne rooms, but a specific ruler was not placed on the throne (with the exception of Croesus). NetHack 3.6.1 adds rulers to throne rooms via commit 4d7d638 and gives them a mace; this is based on a patch by Leon Arnott.[6]

Messages

You hear the tones of courtly conversation.
You hear a sceptre pounded in judgment.
Someone shouts "Off with <his/her> head!"
An occupied throne room is present on the level; the pronoun used matches that of the player character.
You hear Queen Beruthiel's cats!
As above while hallucinating.
You enter an opulent throne room!
You entered an occupied throne room.

Variants

Some variants based on NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions place a "royal" monster on the throne, and some of them additionally provide the monster with an enchanted mace or similar weapon.

GruntHack

GruntHack always generates a king or queen racial monster on the throne of a throne room - this implementation is much different from the L patch that was eventually merged into vanilla NetHack.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, 3⁄4 of throne rooms have a specific ruler with a court of particular monsters accompanying them. Rulers are chosen according to their monster difficulty: a chosen ruler will not have a difficulty greater than the average of your level and the dungeon level difficulty + 5, and will not be lower than 2⁄3 of the dungeon level difficulty. If no prospective ruler fits these criteria, the standard set of throne room rulers are used instead.

The ruler types and corresponding monsters for each room are as follows, roughly sorted in order of monster difficulty:

  • Kobold lord (difficulty 3): Kobold shaman, large kobold, kobold, lemure, imp.
  • Gnome king or gnome queen (difficulty 6): Gnome lord, gnome lady, gnome, gnomish wizard, tinker gnome, dwarf, dwarf lord, dwarf cleric, hobbit, leprechaun, homunculus.
  • Orc-captain (difficulty 7): Orc shaman, Mordor orc, hill orc, hobgoblin, goblin, manes, quasit.
  • Dwarf king or dwarf queen (difficulty 8): Dwarf lord, dwarf cleric, dwarf, gnome, gnome lord, gnome lady, gnomish wizard, hobbit, leprechaun.
  • Ogre king (difficulty 11): Ogre mage, ogre lord, ogre, orc-captain, Mordor orc, tengu, troll, random H.
  • Elvenking or Elvenqueen (difficulty 14): Elf-lord, elf-lady, Grey-elf, Green-elf, Woodland-elf, quickling, dryad, naiad, Coure Eladrin, Noviere Eladrin, Bralani Eladrin, Firre Eladrin, Shiere Eladrin, doppelganger, wood troll.
  • Vampire lord or vampire lady (difficulty 14): Vampire, random Z, random M, flesh golem, werewolf, floating eye, gargoyle, winged gargoyle, quasit, black pudding, wraith, phantasm, ghost, maid, weeping willow, swamp nymph.
  • Drow matron (difficulty 15): Unearthly drow, hedrow wizard, hedrow warrior, drow, sprow, swamp nymph, giant spider, cave lizard, large cave lizard, quasit.
  • Titan (difficulty 20): Storm giant, fire giant, frost giant, hill giant, stone giant, giant, son of Typhon, dryad, naiad, oread, deminymph.
  • Embraced drowess (difficulty 27): Drow alienist, hedrow blademaster, edderkop, hedrow wizard, hedrow warrior, drow mummy.
  • Deepest one (difficulty 33): Deeper one, deep one, human, mind flayer, dark young, umber hulk, stumbling, wandering, and shambling horrors.
  • Orc of the ages of stars (difficulty 37): Deep wyrm, red dragon, white dragon, black dragon, blue dragon, angband orc, hedrow blademaster, succubus, incubus, olog-hai, siege ogre, hell hound.

Some throne rooms have prisoners with a set of shackles that are unconscious and trapped in closets behind iron bars, with the starting inventory they would have normally received placed in that throne room's chest. A character can #untrap these prisoners to free them, which also has a chance of pacifying hostile prisoners if successful.

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, a royal monster always occupies the throne of a throne room, and they are always generated with an ornate mace.

References

  1. ↑ src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 411
  2. ↑ src/mklev.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 763
  3. ↑ src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 348
  4. ↑ src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 738
  5. ↑ src/mkroom.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 247
  6. ↑ Zoos and Courts patch on an archive of L's website

rawPage:
A '''throne room''' is a type of [[special room]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]'', and contains an assortment of [[monster]]s, a [[throne]], and a [[chest]].{{refsrc|src/mkroom.c|411|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} ==Generation== A throne room is generated with a {{frac|6}} chance on ordinary rooms-and-corridors levels from dungeon level 5 onwards, and will only generate if the level does not already have a [[shop]].{{refsrc|src/mklev.c|763|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} The monsters in the throne room will always be generated as hostile and [[asleep]].{{refsrc|src/mkroom.c|348|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} The list of [[throne room monster]]s is as follows:{{refsrc|src/mkroom.c|738|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} * [[dragon]]s (on level 15+) * [[giant humanoid]]s (13+) * [[Troll (monster class)|trolls]] (10+) * [[Centaur (monster class)|centaurs]] (6+) * [[Orc (monster class)|orcs]] * [[bugbear]]s * [[hobgoblin]]s * [[Gnome (monster class)|gnome]]s * [[Kobold (monster class)|kobolds]] Deeper levels are skewed to harder monsters. The limits for ordinary random monsters (based on the average of your and the dungeon floor's level) do not apply. Extinct or genocided monsters from a monster class will be replaced with ordinary random monsters, with the exception of hobgoblins and bugbears. Additionally, the throne will have one of the following monsters occupying it based on [[monster difficulty]], and they are generated with a [[mace]] in addition to their usual [[Monster starting inventory|starting inventory]]:{{refsrc|src/mkroom.c|247|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} * [[ogre king]] * [[Elvenking]] * [[dwarf king]] * [[gnome king]] ===Special levels with throne rooms=== There is a guaranteed throne room in [[Fort Ludios]] (if the Fort is generated at all), with [[Croesus]] seated on the throne. While there are also guaranteed thrones in the [[Castle]] and in [[Vlad's Tower]], the rooms they are located in are not considered throne rooms. ==Strategy== Fighting all the monsters when they are awake can be dangerous for low-level characters, as most of the monsters can generate with [[wand]]s to use against you. Additionally, it is possible for early throne rooms with an otherwise-out of depth monster on the throne to generate - beware the Elvenking who rules over the sixth level! If you have [[stealth]], you can carefully pick off the denizens of a throne room one by one—most throne room monsters are slower than an unhasted player, making them vulnerable to hit-and-run, ranged attacks and/or funneling them into outside hallways. Centaurs are the fastest throne room monsters that can generate, and pose the biggest obstace to the above strategies—they often generate with ranged weapons of their own, and may hit you several times per turn in [[melee]]. If luring throne room monsters into a hallway to fight, beware of monsters zapping a [[wand of digging]] down and leaving a hole between you and the throne room. ==History== Throne rooms first appear in [[NetHack 1.3d]]. From this version to [[NetHack 3.6.0]], "royal" monsters could generate randomly in throne rooms, but a specific ruler was not placed on the throne (with the exception of Croesus). [[NetHack 3.6.1]] adds rulers to throne rooms via {{commit|4d7d63814a99b14acf0bcc96ddf567e966064b78|commit 4d7d638}} and gives them a mace; this is based on a patch by [[L (person)|Leon Arnott]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20180902003105/http://l.j-factor.com/nethack/mkroom.diff Zoos and Courts patch] on an archive of L's website ==Messages== {{message|You hear the tones of courtly conversation.
You hear a sceptre pounded in judgment.
Someone shouts "Off with head!"|An occupied throne room is present on the level; the pronoun used matches that of the player character.}} {{message|You hear Queen Beruthiel's cats!|As above while [[hallucinating]].}} {{message|You enter an opulent throne room!|You entered an occupied throne room.}} ==Variants== Some variants based on [[NetHack 3.4.3]] and earlier versions place a "royal" monster on the throne, and some of them additionally provide the monster with an enchanted mace or similar weapon. ===GruntHack=== [[GruntHack]] always generates a [[King (GruntHack)|king or queen]] [[racial monster]] on the throne of a throne room - this implementation is much different from the L patch that was eventually merged into vanilla ''NetHack''. ===dNetHack=== In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], {{frac|3|4}} of throne rooms have a specific ruler with a court of particular monsters accompanying them. Rulers are chosen according to their monster difficulty: a chosen ruler will not have a difficulty greater than the average of your level and the dungeon level difficulty + 5, and will not be lower than {{frac|2|3}} of the dungeon level difficulty. If no prospective ruler fits these criteria, the standard set of throne room rulers are used instead. The ruler types and corresponding monsters for each room are as follows, roughly sorted in order of monster difficulty: * [[Kobold lord]] (difficulty 3): [[Kobold shaman]], [[large kobold]], [[kobold]], [[lemure]], [[imp]]. * [[Gnome king]] or [[Gnome queen (dNetHack)|gnome queen]] (difficulty 6): [[Gnome lord]], [[Gnome lady (dNetHack)|gnome lady]], [[Gnome (monster)|gnome]], [[gnomish wizard]], [[tinker gnome]], [[Dwarf (monster)|dwarf]], [[dwarf lord]], [[dwarf cleric]], [[hobbit]], [[leprechaun]], [[homunculus]]. * [[Orc-captain]] (difficulty 7): [[Orc shaman]], [[Mordor orc]], [[hill orc]], [[hobgoblin]], [[goblin]], [[manes]], [[quasit]]. * [[Dwarf king]] or [[Dwarf queen (dNetHack)|dwarf queen]] (difficulty 8): [[Dwarf lord]], [[dwarf cleric]], [[Dwarf (monster)|dwarf]], [[Gnome (monster)|gnome]], [[gnome lord]], [[Gnome lady (dNetHack)|gnome lady]], [[gnomish wizard]], [[hobbit]], [[leprechaun]]. * [[Ogre king]] (difficulty 11): [[Ogre mage]], [[ogre lord]], [[ogre]], [[orc-captain]], [[Mordor orc]], [[tengu]], [[troll]], random {{mcsl|H}}. * [[Elvenking]] or [[Elvenqueen (dNetHack)|Elvenqueen]] (difficulty 14): [[Elf-lord]], [[Elf-lady (dNetHack)|elf-lady]], [[Grey-elf]], [[Green-elf]], [[Woodland-elf]], [[quickling]], [[dryad]], [[naiad]], [[Eladrin#Coure Eladrin|Coure Eladrin]], [[Eladrin#Noviere Eladrin|Noviere Eladrin]], [[Eladrin#Bralani Eladrin|Bralani Eladrin]], [[Eladrin#Firre Eladrin|Firre Eladrin]], [[Eladrin#Shiere Eladrin|Shiere Eladrin]], [[doppelganger]], [[wood troll]]. * [[Vampire lord]] or [[Vampire lady (dNetHack)|vampire lady]] (difficulty 14): [[Vampire]], random [[Zombie (dNetHack)|{{white|Z}}]], random {{mcsl|M}}, [[flesh golem]], [[werewolf]], [[floating eye]], [[gargoyle]], [[winged gargoyle]], [[quasit]], [[black pudding]], [[wraith]], [[phantasm]], [[ghost]], [[maid]], [[weeping willow]], [[swamp nymph]]. * [[Drow matron]] (difficulty 15): [[Unearthly drow]], [[hedrow wizard]], [[hedrow warrior]], [[drow]], [[sprow]], [[swamp nymph]], [[giant spider]], [[cave lizard]], [[large cave lizard]], [[quasit]]. * [[Titan]] (difficulty 20): [[Storm giant]], [[fire giant]], [[frost giant]], [[hill giant]], [[stone giant]], [[Giant (monster)|giant]], [[son of Typhon]], [[dryad]], [[naiad]], [[oread]], [[deminymph]]. * [[Embraced drowess]] (difficulty 27): [[Drow alienist]], [[hedrow blademaster]], [[edderkop]], [[hedrow wizard]], [[hedrow warrior]], [[drow mummy]]. * [[Deepest one]] (difficulty 33): [[Deeper one]], [[deep one]], [[human]], [[mind flayer]], [[dark young]], [[umber hulk]], [[Stumbling horror|stumbling]], [[Wandering horror|wandering]], and [[Shambling horror (dNetHack)|shambling horror]]s. * [[Orc of the ages of stars]] (difficulty 37): [[Deep wyrm]], [[red dragon]], [[white dragon]], [[black dragon]], [[blue dragon]], [[angband orc]], [[hedrow blademaster]], [[succubus]], [[incubus]], [[olog-hai]], [[siege ogre]], [[hell hound]]. Some throne rooms have prisoners with a [[set of shackles]] that are unconscious and trapped in closets behind [[iron bars]], with the starting inventory they would have normally received placed in that throne room's chest. A character can #[[untrap]] these prisoners to free them, which also has a chance of pacifying hostile prisoners if successful. ===SlashTHEM=== In [[SlashTHEM]], a royal monster always occupies the throne of a throne room, and they are always generated with an [[Ornate mace (SpliceHack)|ornate mace]]. ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Special rooms]]
